Pro-poor policy, planning and budgeting capacities of national and local level institutions strengthened.
capital of a political entity

comment.narrative: 1. Number of policies, strategies, technical advisory services and studies conducted. 2. Aid management platform and national planning policies developed. 3. Civil service review completed and new strategy formulated, 4. Technical Support for National development planning provided and medium term review of PAGE completed. 5. Support 8 regional and 2 central level consultations on citizens’ budget. 6. Strengthen capacities on planning, aid coordination and PPP.

1. Draft National Planning Policy (2017-2020) developed and to be finalized 2. Aid management system database established and produced aid bulletin and the global report 3. Mid-term review of the PAGE (NDP 2012-2016) conducted 4. Budget consultations conducted within the 8 regions and informed the 2016 budget 5. PPP bankable proposal consultancy commissioned, IT and office equipment, procured for the PPP unit –capacity of the newly created PPP directorate strengthened

1. Recruitment of an International TA for the Ministry of Planning 2. PAGE successor National Development Plan (NDP) produced 3. Finalization of PPP Renewable Energy document 4. Update of the Istanbul Plan of Action 5. Recruitment of 2 IUNVs (Land Valuation, Survey & GIS Specialists) for the Ministry of Local Government 6. Operationalization the national aid management information system –producing national aid management bulletin and global aid survey report 7. Evaluation of the current CPAP

description.narrative: Strengthened statistical capacities for evidence based policy formulation, implementation and monitoring at all levels.
capital of a political entity

comment.narrative: 1. Conduct Integrated Household Survey; 2. Finalize National Statistical Development Strategy and annual data producer and user of statistics forum conducted.

1. Provision of funds to support the IHS Field survey and analysis 2. NSDS II Second Writing workshop conducted with the key stakeholders 3. Annual National Statistical Forum (data producers and user’s forum) conducted.

1. Integrated Household survey progress report available 2. Validation of the National Strategy for Statistical Development 3. Organized a consultative workshop where over 60 statistical producers and users met to agree on key data needs- Demand base statistics created.

Fora on citizen engagement and social audit conducted on adhoc basis; 4. No Action Plan for implementation of 2010 UPR 5. No Gender Policy strategic plan implemented 6. 1.Capacity development in Para Legal training (4), 2.Support implementation of Ministry of Justice strategic plan. 3.Support study tours to learn best practices on the establishment of an Anti corruption Agency and the National Human Rights Commission. 4.Facilitate a Needs Assessment Mission on Electoral Support.

1. 60 people received training in Community Para Legal in 4 regions 2. 2 study tours to Nigeria and Rwanda on Human Rights and anti corruption best practices learning conducted 3. Needs assessment mission on electoral support conducted

1. Support implementation of Ministry of Justice Strategic Plan 2. Conduct mobile legal aid clinics in two regions 3. Decentralize African Gender Development Index activities in all regions 4. Support to IEC on Electoral processes

comment.narrative: 1. Finalize and adopt national social protection policy and strategic plan. 2. Support 2 national and 8 regional consultations. 3. Pilot implementation of minimum package. 4. Support to joint UN programme on HIV AIDS as social protection mechanism.

National social protection forum conducted with regional representatives 3. 300 participants were sensitized nationwide on the newly enacted HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control Act 4. 200 Law Enforcements Agency participants were sensitized on the Newly Enacted HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control Act 5. Institutionalization of the joint UN group on social protection 6. Capacitized the national institutions and structures responsible for social protection e..g served in the national steering committee and other advisory bodies on social protection)

Small producers, particularly women, youths and vulnerable groups, access and utilize productive resources and markets through value addition facilities and services.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1. No of knowledge products produced. 2. No value addition of primary commodities: 3. No assessment of situation of women's access and ownership to land and other productive resource.

1. 80 youths benefitting from agricultural transformation for growth and employment generation capacity development training. 2. Best practice learning on cluster development and industrial estate facilitated.

1. Study tour on cluster development & industrial estate learning best practice which provided informed actions 2. Innovative process methodologies, packaging and labeling strategies for small producers. 3. Annual work plan for Songhai initiation project which supported five productive activities of the Centre e.g. horticulture, livestock, agroforestry, poultry, crops- created over 80 direct jobs and 580 indirect employment. 4. 29 Youth Trainees returned from Songhai Centre in Benin and completed another six months at the Centre in Chamen as trainee instructors (out of this 29 youths, 21 of them have already secured formal employment) 5. 40 young people recruited from all over the country have commenced a fully funded twelve months training at the GSI Centre in Chamen while another 35 are in their final stage of training at the same Centre.

1. Conduct an Impact Assessment of MSMEs in Growth, Employment and Poverty. 2. Recruitment of a driver and project Coordinator 3. Development of a complete Project document and Resource Mobilization Forum 4. Operationalization of the youth employment and agricultural entrepreneur -Chamen Center

description.narrative: Capabilities for skills, access to technology, information and knowledge for women, youth and vulnerable groups enhanced.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1. No Skill gap analysis report produced: 2. Limited number of people received apprenticeship training; 3. No Tracer study on TVET conducted; 4. No Agro based incubation center established and operationalized: 5. No LMIS established 6. 2 employment staff trained on employment & labour administration system: 7. No dialogue forum for PPP held and action plan developed: 8. Awareness on employment issues increased; advocacy through TV and radio and newsletters: started in 2012 9. No drama group on employment issues.

1. Support entrepreneurship capacity development at all levels to increase the contribution of SMEs to growth, employment creation and poverty reduction. 2. Train 400 entrepreneurs and 200 Business Development Services providers. Entrepreneurship development center established. 3. Strengthen national capacity for entrepreneurship development, promotion of marketable skills and best practice on youth employment endeavors. 4. Strengthen capacity of the employment / investment and labour directorates and also update national employment policy.

1. National Youth Employment forum regional consultation 2. Consultancy for the Update of the National Employment Policy 2010 – 2014 recruited 3. Entrepreneurship Development Centre established and functioning 4. Entrepreneurship knowledge and skills promoted across the country benefiting directly 850 people through the training of trainers for entrepreneurial training, agri-business training and training of business development advisors. 5. Productivity and job creation capacity of MSMEs enhanced through the provision of continuous and inclusive business advisory services 6. 11 trainers, 29 Business Advisor, 390 Entrepreneurs Trained.

1. Capacity building through training of Employment Unit staff and key partners by the UNV Employment Specialist (In-House Training) 2. Occupational Safety and Health Sensitization Workshops (Rural Areas) 3. Review of Labour Act 2007 (consultancy & Validation) 4. Popularization and dissemination of the revised national youth policy & sensitizations on the dangers of youth irregular migration

description.narrative: Support and promote community based natural resources management initiatives such as ecotourism.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1. sustainable use of environmental resources enhanced through : +Training of wildlife rangers, + Development of at least one by-law and 4 management plans for community protected areas, + Tree planting, woodlots development, training of 35 community representatives on modern honey production and one community on ecotourism promotion

1. 20 wildlife Rangers were trained on resource protection. (9 from Basse, 3 from Kerewan and 8 from WCR) which contributed to better Protected Area Management and sustainable use in the targeted areas. 2. Eight community natural resources management by-laws developed and four protected Area Management Plans prepared with the active participation of all stakeholders which contributed to better law enforcement, better management and sustainable use of local resources & enhanced community capacity in resource management. Tree planting (Mangrove and indigenous species) conducted, which contributed to increased income, environmental protection and enhanced community capacity in tree nursery manaemgent 2. 35 participants were trained on modern honey production and value addition in 8 CF/JFPM committees currently engaged in honey production which resulted to improved forest resource protection, additional income generation and sustainable livelihood venture for the concerned communities , . 3. Over 1000 brochures on the fauna and flora of Kunkiling forest park developed and the dilapidated tomb of Musa Molloh in the vicinity of the park refurbished which contributed to increased visitation from 50 in 2014 to over 150 visitors in 2015) to the park, cultural heritage protection and increased awareness on forest resources for improved livelihoods.

1. Capacities of women in community forest communities enhanced in collection, preservation and processing techniques of forest fruits and nuts; Support provided for the designation process of forestland management and ownership from state own to community ownership and management. 2. Assessment of tree nursery and seedling multiplication activity at Jarume Koto conducted

title.narrative: Enhancing Resilience of Vulnerable Communities & Areas

description.narrative: The risk of climate change induced damage to human and economic development in coastal areas of The Gambia is mounting with sea level rise and coastal erosion.

policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 0 for all the indicators below.

1. Regulatory requirements for works at Senegambia/Tanji,Tendaba,Darsilami and Illiassa. 2. Identification of Contractors for village defense works in Tendaba. 3. Identification of Contractors for coastal defense works in Senegambia/Kololi and Tanji Bridge. 4. Support to alternative livelihood activities and programs. 5. A study on mangrove restoration planning completed and mangrove replanting commenced: 6. Execute village defense works in Tendaba. 7. Execute Integrated Farming System in Darsilami and Illiassa. 8. Execute coastal defense works in Senegambia/Kololi and Tanji Bridge.

description.narrative: To reduce Gambias vulnerability to sealevel rise and associated impacts of climate change by improving coastal defences and enhancing adaptive capacities of coastal communities
Number of vulnerable people communities with enhanced living conditions and sustainable livelihoods

comment.narrative:
Zero within government sector minimal and sporadic in tourist sector
Zero existing communities affected by negative climate impacts socioeconomic and or environmental

Investment level reaches an additional USD 15m for sea and river defences allied to risk reduction approach
All target communities wards experience positive improvements and sustainable livelihoods

Designs for Sea River defense produced for three locations as follows SenegambiaKololi Beach Tanji Bridge and Tendaba Supervisors for the construction of designs for SenegambiaKololi and Tendaba already identified
Designs for a farming system that integrates rice cultivation fish farming and salt production produced for Dasilami and Illiasa shortlist of candidates for supervision of the construction activity produced

description.narrative: Policies institutions and individuals mandated to manage coastal areas strengthened to reduce the risk of climate change

Climate risk management sea and river risk management and technical capacity in relevant national and regional institutions
Coastal monitoring procedure undertaken collated in database and accessible to support decisionmaking
Number of Sea and River Defence Investment Plans actually financed

comment.narrative:
Negligible except in NEA and DWR
Very limited monitoring database
None

Capacity to implement climate risk management in national institutions and target regional entities 250 Technicians trained in total 50 technical staff drawn from national departments 200 extension staff drawn from relevant regional agricultural engineering planning and fisheries directorates
Monitoring data collected and stored in structured and accessible database
Sea and River Defence policy and investment management plans SRDIMPs Code of Practice for Sea and River Defence Structures Coastal Development developed SRDIMP developed 1 per each coastal district

Thirteen technical staff trained from national departments and fifteen 15 extension staff trained from the regions
Not much of monitoring data collected during period as M E Officer was largely not available project will make of use monitoring database being developed by the EUGlobal Climate Change Alliance project also being implemented by National Environment Agency
Guidance manual on Sea River Defense Risk Management produced

description.narrative: Rural livelihoods in the coastal zone enhanced and protected from the impacts of climate change through the demonstration and the transfer of successful coastal adaptation technologies and the introduction of economic diversification

Rice and fish production to produce sustainable income for local community
Number of farmers that will receive agricultural extension services and alternative livelihoods

comment.narrative:
Uneconomic degraded rice production and no fish ranching production in target communities
No negligible knowledge on farmers that will receive agricultural extension

Rice and fish production represent economic sustainable livelihood activity for community members in 20 wards in the Lower and Central Valleys 1500 rice growers and 300 horticulture producers diversity income

Design for an integrated rice salt and fish farming scheme produced for Dasilami and Illiasa communities working at ward level is not practical Five communities received support in horticulture with combined beneficiaries of 671 men and female that is expected to increase

description.narrative: Vulnerability of coastal investments to climate risks reduced through the design construction and maintenance of coastal protection measures

Number of hard and soft coastal protection schemes implemented to reduce erosion risks
Number of families benefiting from LDCF resources used for design and build structures

comment.narrative:
No functioning hard or soft protection or redundant legacy structures at target sites
Vulnerable communities to climate change in coastal and estuarine areas are becoming in higher risk without adaptation measures

2 Hard and 3 soft protection schemes planned and implemented
1500 families will benefit directly from protection measures

Studies completed and designs for two hard engineering protection measures produced for SenegambiaKololi beach and Tanji Bridge Designs for soft engineering measures produced for the three locations of Dasilami Illiasa and Tendaba Supervisors identified for construction works in SenegambiaKololi and Tanji Bridge same supervisor and also for Tendaba
More than 1500 families expected to benefit at the completion and operation of the measures

title.narrative: Early Warning-Strengthening Climate Services in Gambia
Early Warning-Strengthening Climate Services in Gambia

description.narrative: Strengthening climate services and early warning systems in the Gambia for climate resilient development and adaptation to climate change - 2nd Phase.
1. Percentage of national coverage by monitoring network by end of project and percentage of coverage by an automated network.

comment.narrative: 1. 50% of the National territory covered by a monitoring system at present, 0% of which is automated.
1. Hydrological/meteorological infrastructure procured and installed for optimal performance of national hydro-met monitoring system. 2. 4 meteorological stations constructed.

title.narrative: Support to National Ebola Prevention and Preparedness in

description.narrative: Support to National Ebola Prevention and Preparedness in The Gambia
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of end-to-end early warning systems for man-made crisis and all major natural hazards (e.g. geo-physical and climate-induced hazards)
Number of preparedness plans that cover only response
Number of preparedness plans that cover response AND recovery
Support The Gambia’s National Ebola Virus Disease Plan (NEVDP) & is to improve national capacities to implement the NEVDP, by enhancing national response capacities and preparedness levels.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1.Number of coordination meetings taking place regularly at national and regional level. 2.Number of Health workers training to deal adequately with EVD. 3. Number of awareness creation and social mobilization activities completed on EVD preparedness and response plan. 4. Availability of a system to effectively manage case, early detection and referral systems and mechanisms.

comment.narrative: 1. Absence of a Central Emergency Command Centre with the necessary vehicles and equipment. 2. Inadequate transport facilities to undertake coordination, monitoring and evaluation activities at field level. 3. Absence of a national Project Coordination Unit for EVD prevention and control. 4. Stakeholder meetings are not conducted on a regular basis, particularly at regional level. 5. Inadequate resources to conduct bimonthly supervisory visits. 6. Lack of skills in EVD prevention and management, especially at community level. 7. IHR (2005) not utilized as the basis for health interventions.

1. Central Emergency Command Centre operational and fully equipped with computers and well connected VHF radio network. 2.35 border officers and 105 community-based nurses trained on EVD prevention and control. 3.100% of Rapid Response Teams trained on surveillance and early detection. 4.35 field surveillance officers (5 per Region) trained on contact tracing, reporting and follow-up. 5.100 Community Health Nurses trained on community case-based definition of alert cases of EVD, using Training of Trainers approach. 6. Drama groups and traditional communicators engaged to conduct national sensitization campaigns on EVD. 7. EVD sensitization campaigns conducted in each region. 8. Increased levels of awareness on EVD prevention and detection, particularly at local community level. 9.Temporary holding facilities established and equipped at three Points of Entry.
